channel.title: Data on Aspose.Cells Product Family
channel.description: Recent content in Data on Aspose.Cells Product Family

item.title: Accessing Cells of a Worksheet
item.description: We know that all worksheets may contain data that is basically stored in cells (with which a worksheet is made up of). A cell is a basic part of a worksheet that is used to construct the whole worksheet as a sequence of rows and columns. Before we try to access data from a worksheet, we would need to get access to its cells. So, in this topic, we will discuss some basic approaches to access worksheet cells at runtime using Aspose.

item.title: Add and Retrieve Data
item.description: In Accessing Cells of a Worksheet, we discussed basic approaches for accessing cells in a worksheet. This article uses one of those approaches to add different types of data to cells. Contents Summary 1 Adding Data to Cells 1.1 Improving Efficiency 2 Retrieving Data from Cells | Adding Data to Cells Aspose.Cells provides a class, Workbook, that represents a Microsoft Excel file.

item.title: Cells Formatting
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Adding Borders to Cells 1.1 Adding Borders to Cells 1.1.1 Adding Borders to a Cell 1.1.2 Adding Borders to a Range of Cells 2 Colors and Palette 2.1 Adding Custom Colors to Palette 3 Colors and Background Patterns 3.1 Setting Colors and Background Patterns 3.2 Important to Know | Adding Borders to Cells Microsoft Excel allows users to format cells by adding borders.

item.title: Format Cells using GetStyle and SetStyle Methods
item.description: Aspose.Cells provides the GetStyle and SetStyle methods of the Cell class, used to get/set the formatting style of a cell. Aspose.Cells also provides a Style class. Contents Summary 1 Format Cells using GetStyle and SetStyle Methods 1.1 Using the GetStyle and SetStyle Methods 1.2 Using Style Object to Format Different Cells 1.3 Using Microsoft Excel 2007 Predefined Styles 1.4 Applying Gradient Fill Effects || Format Cells using GetStyle and SetStyle Methods Apply different kinds of formatting styles on cells to set background or foreground colors, borders, fonts, horizontal and vertical alignments, indentation level, text direction, rotation angle and much more.

item.title: Excel 2007 Themes and Colors
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Excel 2007 Themes and Colors 1.1 Get and Set Theme Colors 1.1.1 Customize Themes 1.1.2 Use Theme Colors || Excel 2007 Themes and Colors Themes provide a unified look with named styles, graphical effects and other objects used in a workbook. For example, the Accent1 style, for example, looks different in the Office and the Apex themes.

item.title: Conditional Formatting
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Introduction 2 Applying Conditional Formatting 2.1 Using Designer Spreadsheet 2.2 Using the Copy Method 3 Applying Conditional Formatting at Runtime 3.1 Set Font 3.2 Set Border 3.3 Set Pattern | Introduction Conditional formatting is an advanced Microsoft Excel feature that allows you to apply formats to a cell or range of cells and have that formatting change depending on the value of the cell or the value of a formula.

item.title: Apply Advanced Conditional Formatting
item.description: Microsoft Excel 2007 and later versions (2010/2013/2016) provides some advanced features for conditional formatting. For example, it lets you apply cell shading, borders, colored icons, arrows, flags and font formatting, etc. which has become quite sophisticated. Contents Summary 1 Apply Advanced Conditional Formatting to Microsoft Excel Files 1.1 Compute the Color Chosen by Microsoft Excel for ColorScale Conditional Formatting || Apply Advanced Conditional Formatting to Microsoft Excel Files Conditional formatting can:

item.title: Creating Subtotals
item.description: You can automatically create subtotals for any repeating values in a spreadsheet. Aspose.Cells provides API features that help you add subtotals to spreadsheets programmatically. Contents Summary 1 Using Microsoft Excel 2 Using the Aspose.Cells API | Using Microsoft Excel To add subtotals in Microsoft Excel: Create a simple data list in the first worksheet of the workbook (as shown in the figure below) and save the file as Book1.

item.title: Data Validation
item.description: Microsoft Excel provides some good features to auto filter or validate worksheet data.Aspose.Cells fully supports Microsoft Excel’s data validation and AutoFilter features. This article explains how to use the features in Microsoft Excel, and how to code them using Aspose.Cells. Contents Summary 1 Data Validation Types and Execution 1.1 Data Validation with Microsoft Excel 1.2 Data Validation with Aspose.Cells 1.2.1 Types of Data Validation 1.2.1.1 Whole Number Data Validation

item.title: Data Formatting
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Introduction 2 Format Data in Cells 3 Setting Display Formats of Numbers and Dates 3.1 Setting Display Formats in Microsoft Excel 3.2 Using Built-in Number Formats 3.3 Using Custom Number Formats 4 Formatting Selected Characters in a Cell 4.1 Formatting Selected Characters 5 Activating Sheets and Making an Active Cell in the Worksheet 5.1 Activating Sheets and Making a Cell Active 6 Formatting Rows and Columns 6.

item.title: Specifying DBNum Custom Pattern Formatting
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Sample Code || Possible Usage Scenarios Aspose.Cells supports the *DBNum *custom pattern formatting. For example, if your cell value is 123 and you specify its custom formatting as [DBNum2][$-804]General then it will be displayed like 壹佰贰拾叁. You can specify your custom formatting of the cell using Cell.GetStyle() method and Style.Custom property. Sample Code The following sample code illustrates

item.title: Configuring Alignment Settings
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Configuring Alignment Settings 1.1 Alignment settings in Microsoft Excel 1.2 Alignment settings in Aspose.Cells 1.2.1 Horizontal Alignment 1.2.2 Vertical Alignment 1.2.3 Indentation 1.2.4 Orientation 1.2.5 Text Control 1.2.5.1 Wrapping Text 1.2.5.2 Shrinking to Fit 1.2.5.3 Merging Cells 1.2.5.4 Text Direction | Configuring Alignment Settings Alignment settings in Microsoft Excel Anyone who has used Microsoft Excel to format cells will be familiar with the alignment settings in Microsoft Excel.

item.title: Data Sorting
item.description: Data sorting is one of Microsoft Excel’s many useful features. It allows users to order data to make it easier to scan. Aspose.Cells lets developers sort worksheet data alphabetically or numerically which works in the same way as Microsoft Excel does to sort data. Contents Summary 1 Sorting Data in Microsoft Excel 2 Sorting Data with Aspose.Cells 2.1 Sorting data with background colour | Sorting Data in Microsoft Excel To sort data in Microsoft Excel:

item.title: Specifying Sort Warning While Sorting Data
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Sample Code || Possible Usage Scenarios Please consider this textual data i.e. {11, 111, 22}. This textual data is sorted because, in terms of text, 111 comes before 22. But, if you want to sort this data not as text but as numbers, then it will become {11, 22, 111} because numerically 111 comes after 22.

item.title: Dealing with Font Settings
item.description: The look and feel of a text can be controlled by changing font settings. The font settings may include the name, style, size, color and other effects of the fonts. Just like Microsoft Excel, Aspose.Cells also supports configuring the font settings of the cells. Contents Summary 1 Configuring Font Settings 1.1 Setting Font Name 1.2 Setting Font Style to Bold 1.3 Setting Font Size 1.4 Setting Font Color

item.title: Find or Search Data
item.description: Microsoft Excel allows users to find cells in a worksheet that contains specified data. Contents Summary 1 Finding Cells Containing Specified Data 1.1 Using Microsoft Excel 1.2 Using Aspose.Cells 2 Finding Cells Containing a Formula 3 Finding Data or Formulas using FindOptions 4 Finding Cells Containing Specified String Value or Number | Finding Cells Containing Specified Data Using Microsoft Excel

item.title: Import Data into Worksheet
item.description: This article discusses some data import techniques that developers have access to through Aspose.Cells. Contents Summary 1 Import Data into Worksheet 1.1 Importing from Array 1.2 Importing from ArrayList 1.3 Importing from Custom Objects 1.4 Importing from Custom Objects to merged area 1.5 Importing from DataTable 1.6 Importing from dynamic object as data source 1.7 Importing from DataColumn (.NET) 1.8 Importing from DataView (.NET) 1.9 Importing from DataGrid (.

item.title: Export Data from Worksheet
item.description: This article discusses some data export techniques that developers have access to through Aspose.Cells. Contents Summary 1 Export Data from Worksheet 1.1 Exporting Data to DataTable Using Aspose.Cells 1.1.1 Columns Containing Strongly Typed Data 1.1.2 Columns Containing Non-Strongly Typed Data 1.1.3 Export Range with flag to skip column name | Export Data from Worksheet Aspose.Cells not only facilitates its users to import data to worksheets from external data sources but also allow them to export their worksheet data to a DataTable.

item.title: Merging and Unmerging Cells
item.description: Aspose.Cells supports this feature and can also merge cells in a worksheet. You may unmerge, or split, the merged cells too. A merged cell’s cell reference is the reference for the top left cell in the original selected range. Contents Summary 1 Introduction 2 Merging Cells in a Worksheet 2.1 Merging Cells in Microsoft Excel 2.2 Merging Cells with Aspose.Cells 3 Unmerging (Splitting) Merged Cells 3.1 Using Microsoft Excel

item.title: Create Access and Copy Named Ranges
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Introduction 2 Working with Named Range Using Microsoft Excel 2.1 Create Named Ranges 3 Working with Named Range Using Aspose.Cells 3.1 Create Named Range 3.2 Input Data into the Cells in the Named Range 3.3 Identify Cells in the Named Range 3.4 Access Named Ranges 3.4.1 Access a Specific Named Range 3.4.2 Access All the Named Ranges in a Spreadsheet 3.5 Copy Named Ranges

item.title: Format and Modify Named Ranges
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Format Ranges 1.1 Setting Background Color and Font Attributes to a Named Range 1.2 Adding Borders to a Named Range 2 Rename a Named Range 3 Union of Ranges 4 Intersection of Ranges 5 Merge Cells in the Named Range 6 Remove a Named Range | Format Ranges Setting Background Color and Font Attributes to a Named Range

item.title: Setting Formula for Named Range
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Setting Formula for Named Range 1.1 Setting a Simple Formula for Named Range 1.2 Setting a Complex Formula for Named Range | Setting Formula for Named Range Like Excel application, Aspose.Cells APIs provide the ability to specify a formula for a named range while using its RefersTo property. There could be numerous usability scenarios for this feature, a few of which are detailed as follow.

item.title: Precedents and Dependents
item.description: Complex financial worksheets, especially ones developed in collaboration, can hide the most embarrassing errors. Checking formulas for accuracy and finding the source of an error can be difficult when the formula uses precedent cells and dependent cells. Contents Summary 1 Introduction 2 Tracing Precedent and Dependent Cells: Microsoft Excel 3 Tracing Precedent and Dependent Cells: Aspose.Cells 3.1 Tracing Precedents 3.2 Tracing Dependents | Introduction Precedent cells are cells that are referred to by a formula in another Cell.

item.title: Working with Hyperlinks to Link Data
item.description: A hyperlink is used to create a link between two entities. Everybody is familiar with the use of hyperlinks, especially on websites. Using Aspose.Cells, developers can create different kinds of hyperlinks in Microsoft Excel files. This topic discusses what types of hyperlinks are supported by Aspose.Cells and how they can be used in our Excel files. Contents Summary 1 Adding Hyperlinks 1.1 Adding Link to a URL

item.title: Rename duplicate columns automatically while exporting worksheet data
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Rename duplicate columns automatically while exporting worksheet data 3 Sample Code 4 Console Output | Possible Usage Scenarios Sometimes user faces a problem of duplicate columns while exporting data from worksheet into the data table. DataTable cannot have duplicate columns so duplicate columns must be renamed before you could export worksheet data to the data table.

item.title: Export HTML String Value of the Cells to the DataTable
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Export HTML String Value of the Cells to the DataTable 3 Screenshot 4 Sample Code 5 Console Output | Possible Usage Scenarios Using Aspose.Cells APIs, developers can fill a DataTable with corresponding HTML strings (based on cells values) while exporting worksheet data. This document explains how to export HTML strings for the formatted cells data to fill a DataTable using Aspose.

item.title: Shift First Row down when inserting Cells Data Table Rows
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Shift First Row down when inserting Cells Data Table Rows 3 Screenshot 4 Sample Code | Possible Usage Scenarios Aspose.Cells allows you to shift the first row down when inserting a table into the worksheet. This document explains how you may accomplish the task using Aspose.Cells APIs. Shift First Row down when inserting Cells Data Table Rows

item.title: Apply Advanced Filter of Microsoft Excel to Display Records Meeting Complex Criteria
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Apply Advanced Filter of Microsoft Excel to Display Records Meeting Complex Criteria 3 Sample Code | Possible Usage Scenarios Microsoft Excel allows you to apply Advanced Filter on worksheet data to display records that meet complex criteria. You can apply Advanced Filter with Microsoft Excel via its Data > Advanced command as shown in this screenshot.

item.title: Sort Data in Column with Custom Sort List
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Sort Data in Column with Custom Sort List 3 Sample Code | **Possible Usage Scenarios ** You can sort data in the column using a custom list. This can be done using DataSorter.AddKey(int key, SortOrder order, String customList) method. However, this method works only if the items in the custom list do not have commas inside them.

item.title: Specify Formula Fields while Importing Data to Worksheet
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Specify Formula Fields while Importing Data to Worksheet 3 Sample Code | Possible Usage Scenarios You can specify formula fields when you import data into your worksheet using the ImportTableOptions.IsFormulas. This property takes the Boolean array where the value true means the field is a formula field. For example, if the third field is a formula field, then the third value in the array will be true.

item.title: Preserve Single Quote Prefix of Cell Value or Range
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Preserve Single Quote Prefix of Cell Value or Range 3 Sample Code 4 Console Output | Possible Usage Scenarios When you put some value inside the cell that has leading apostrophe or single quote mark, then Microsoft Excel hides it, but when you select the cell, it displays the leading apostrophe or single quote in a formula bar as shown in the following screenshot.

item.title: Get All Hidden Rows Indices after Refreshing AutoFilter
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Get All Hidden Rows Indices after Refreshing AutoFilter 3 Sample Code 4 Console Output | Possible Usage Scenarios When you apply the auto filter on worksheet cells, then some of the rows get hidden automatically. But it might be the case that some of the rows are already hidden manually by Excel end user and they are not hidden by an auto filter.

item.title: Get Address Cell Count Offset Entire Column and Entire Row of the Range
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Get Address, Cell Count, Offset, Entire Column and Entire Row of the Range 3 Sample Code 4 Console Output | Possible Usage Scenarios Aspose.Cells provides the Range object which has various utility methods that facilitate the user to work with Excel Ranges easily. This article illustrates the usage of the following methods or properties of Range object.

item.title: Change Cells Alignment and Keep Existing Formatting
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Possible Usage Scenarios 2 Change Cells Alignment and Keep Existing Formatting 3 Sample Code | Possible Usage Scenarios Sometimes, you want to change the alignment of multiple cells but also want to keep existing formatting. Aspose.Cells allows you to do it using the StyleFlag.Alignments property. If you will set it true, changes in alignment will take place otherwise not.

item.title: Data Filtering
item.description: Microsoft Excel provides some good features to autofilter worksheet data. Aspose.Cells fully supports Microsoft Excel’s autofilter features. This article explains how to use the features in Microsoft Excel, and how to code them using Aspose.Cells. Contents Summary 1 Autofilter Data 1.1 Autofilter in Microsoft Excel 1.2 Autofilter with Aspose.Cells 1.2.1 Different types of Filter 1.2.1.1 Fill Color 1.2.1.2 Date 1.2.1.3 Dynamic Date 1.2.1.4 Number 1.2.1.5 Text 1.2.1.6 Blanks

item.title: Create Union Range
item.description: Contents Summary 1 Create Union Range | Create Union Range Aspose.Cells provides the ability to create Union Range by using the WorksheetCollection.CreateUnionRange method. The WorksheetCollection.CreateUnionRange method accepts two parameters, the address to create the union range and the index of the worksheet. The WorksheetCollection.CreateUnionRange method returns a UnionRange object. The following code snippet demonstrates creating a Union Range by using the WorksheetCollection.
